body:
I don't think it's a good idea to always highlight regex matches for performance reasons.

> An alternative is to have the strings matched by a regex highlighted when in Hints mode, similar to how it is in Search mode.

Isn't this already the case? When you start hint mode, all matches should be highlighted.

> When you start hint mode, all matches should be highlighted.

As long as I'm not missing something: only the hints labels are highlighted, not the strings themselves:
![3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/60102027/177080762-f3e2f0f7-1bde-4a19-892a-7a7c4491ffd4.png)

Unlike in Search mode where the full string is colored:
![2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/60102027/177081647-ec8ffe5f-24fa-4fa4-8830-4a2bf31bcc76.png)

colors.hints only has settings for:

- start # First character in the hint label
- end # All characters after the first one in the hint label

My full colors section, if it would help.
```
colors:
  primary:
    background: '#050505'
    foreground: '#eeeeee'
  cursor:
    text: '#080808'
    cursor: '#33ee33'
  vi_mode_cursor:
    text: '#080808'
    cursor: '#33ee33'
  search:
    matches:
      foreground: '#080808'
      background: '#3388ff'
    focused_match:
      foreground: '#080808'
      background: '#33ff88'
    bar:
      background: '#3388ff'
      foreground: '#080808'
  hints:
    start:
      foreground: '#080808'
      background: '#33ff88'
    end:
      foreground: '#0000ff'
      background: '#3388ff'
  line_indicator:
    foreground: '#080808'
    background: '#00ff00'
  selection:
    text: CellBackground
    background: CellForeground

  normal:
    black:   '#000000'
    red:     '#ff0000'
    green:   '#00ee00'
    yellow:  '#ffff00'
    blue:    '#5588ff'
    magenta: '#00ee00'
    cyan:    '#3388ff'
    white:   '#ffffff'

  bright:
    black:   '#555555'
    red:     '#eeee00'
    green:   '#88ee33'
    yellow:  '#ffdd55'
    blue:    '#77aadd'
    magenta: '#aa88aa'
    cyan:    '#11bb22'
    white:   '#eeeeee'
```
What benefit are you trying to achieve? Just to figure out where the regex matches end? If so I'd say we could potentially underline the full match in our regex hint matching logic.

> Just to figure out where the regex matches end?

Yes, that is exactly what I want. Underlining the full match would achieve that.
Seems reasonable to me, that way people will know exactly what was matched.

issue.title: issue #6178 - fixed hint highlighting
issue.body:
#6178 
I found the reason why only the first character of the hint match got highlighted and tried to fix it.

line 448
` self.labels[self.matches.index].get(label_position).copied().map(|c| (c, is_first)`

If label_position was not 0 then None got returned, thats what caused the issue. I changed it to 0, everything seems to be working now, nothing should be broken.
Also added underlining for the rest of the hint.
![alacritty_screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/83160118/179070842-41503c44-6e13-4eba-ac62-4246f8f5e814.png)

body:
I don't use mobaxterm myself, but it does have this feature, as do a few other terminals (see https://saravanaj.github.io/2021/07/15/mobaxterm-like-keyword-highlighting-in-linux-terminal/). 

While I agree it could affect performance, it should only do that for those have it enabled. It may also be acceptable to be lazy about the evaluation, if there is some sort of 'idle' state that can trigger it, for example. Or maybe a toggle key to turn it on and off?

It would be great to define a custom list of regex strings:

- err.*
- warn(ing)?

and so on, associating each of them with a highlight.

If performance is an issue, it could be configurable to let the user decide whether to activate it.

MobaXterm implements this functionality, and it is extremely convenient.

perf is not an issue here, it's a matter of setting highlight bit at this point, given that all the code is in place, it's just not highlighted by default.

if you want just regexes and click/copy text just define them in the config.

What I mean is something like this:

![image](https://github.com/alacritty/alacritty/assets/13739892/92de5d90-c077-4596-9d0a-f60606d26d47)

It would be great to add custom regex patterns associating them with a colour (background, foreground).

Those highlights should be active the whole time without manually triggering them and applied as soon as the matched regex is found in the terminal buffer, eventually by just providing the highlight functionality (but if an action/command could be associated with them, even better).

issue.title: Underline hint matches during selection
issue.body:
This patch underlines the full regex hint match while the keyboard hint selection is in process.

While it would be possible to color the entire match, this would only introduce unnecessary configuration options and be too noisy. The underline matches the mouse highlighting and has a less drastic visual impact.

Closes #6178.

body: We have a patch to underline though, which should probably be enough? The #7226 PR.
Yeah underline is just superior to colors in this scenario. For anyone who disagrees, forking #7226 to use colors instead would be extremely trivial.

I have not understood if with the aforementioned commit, it will be possible to automatically highlight/underline the regex patterns as soon as those are shown in the buffer (for example error strings during compiling), or if it will be needed everytime to manually trigger the underline / highlight for example with an hotkey.
The said commit requires manually triggering. Which is what initially was requested, since hints were missing the ability to show what exactly got matched.
Just to add to this: Permanent highlighting is also not something that will be added or considered in the future. It's just too inefficient.
